fields.title: Comprehensive Food Security and Vulnerability Analysis
Multi Cluster Initial and Rapid Assessment
Violence against personnel, facilities and assets
Interference into implementation of humanitarian activities
Restriction of movement (impediments to freedom of movement and/or administrative restrictions)
Impediments to entry into country (bureaucratic and administrative)
Restriction and obstruction of access to services and assistance
Denial of existence of humanitarian needs or entitlements to assistance
Access of People in need to Aid
Access of Humanitarian Actors to Affected Populations
Presence of mines and improvised explosive devices
Physical constraints in the environment (obstacles related to terrain, climate, lack of infrastructure, etc.)

fields.description: Opinions from population and assessment teams were captured and contrasted
fields.title: Inclusiveness

fields.description: Data and methods are accessible and documented enough to allow reproducibility and further analysis if required
fields.title: Reproducibility

fields.description: Subject matter experts agree with the findings and results of the assessment
fields.title: Consensus

fields.description: Contrary information, outliers or inconsistencies not consistent with the line of analysis are clearly highlighted and communicated
fields.title: Clearly stated outliers

fields.description: Results uses or contributes to Common Operational Datasets
fields.title: Comparability

fields.description: Results are plausible, logical in context
fields.title: Plausibility

fields.description: Data, evidence, and tools supporting judgments are available, documented and clearly sourced
fields.title: Sourced data and evidence

fields.description: At least one structured analytical technique was used for each analytical level
fields.title: Structured Analytical Techniques

fields.description: Efforts were made to use different methods and independent sources and triangulate results
fields.title: Triangulation

fields.description: Charts, tables, and maps are used to illustrate results in a compelling and efficient way
fields.title: Illustrations

fields.description: Results are available at least for two levels of breakdown (sector/sub-sector, Admin2/3, Affected groups level 2/3, etc.) and are broken down by relevant categories of analysis (sex, age, urban/rural, Conflict/no conflict, etc.)
fields.title: Granularity

fields.description: Results were available on time to inform decision-making
fields.title: Timeliness

fields.description: Methodology used is following golden standards/official guidelines and uses an analysis framework and plan
fields.title: Methods

fields.description: Results are corroborated and convergent across different independent sources
fields.title: Corroboration

fields.description: Levels of confidence in estimates are available as well as reasons for uncertainty
fields.title: Levels of confidence

fields.description: Results cover all affected geographical areas, groups, and sectors
fields.title: Comprehensiveness

fields.description: Results are articulated using a clear line of analysis and “Bottom Line Up Front”
fields.title: Clearly articulated results

fields.description: Key assumptions, information gaps, and alternative explanations or inconsistencies are identified, clearly communicated and caveated
fields.title: Assumptions

fields.description: Authors of the reports are reliable (Track record for accuracy, technical expertise, motive for bias)
fields.title: Source reliability

fields.description: Results answers the original research questions or objectives, bring new or additional information and fill previous information gaps
fields.title: Relevance
Priority issues/unmet needs, underlying factors and intensity/severity, forecasted priority issues/unmet needs, operational recommendations
Priority issues/unmet needs, underlying factors and intensity/severity, forecasted priority issues/unmet needs
Priority issues/unmet needs, underlying factors, intensity/severity and operational recommendations
Priority issues/unmet needs, underlying factors and intensity/severity
Priority issues/unmet needs and underlying factors
Good, representative PIN numbers by severity grades
Rough PIN estimates by severity grade
Acknowledge dissenting voices in joint needs analysis
Acknowledge dissenting voices in joint needs analysis
Informed consent, confidentiality and data security
Buy-in and use by humanitarian clusters / sectors
Buy-in and use by UN agencies
Buy-in and use by international non-governmental organizations (INGOs)
Buy-in and use by local non-governmental organizations (local NGOs)
Buy-in and use by members of the Red Cross / Red Crescent Movement
Buy-in and use by national and local government agencies
Buy-in and use by development and stabilization actors
Buy-in and use by humanitarian clusters / sectors
Buy-in and use by UN agencies
Buy-in and use by international non-governmental organizations (INGOs)
Buy-in and use by local non-governmental organizations (local NGOs)
Buy-in and use by members of the Red Cross / Red Crescent Movement
Buy-in and use by national and local government agencies
Buy-in and use by development and stabilization actors

fields.text: The HNO builds on a thorough mapping of existing needs assessments (assessment registry).
The HNO covers all areas affected by the crisis.
Within the affected areas, HNO results are broken down at least to administrative level 2 (district).
The HNO covers all relevant humanitarian sectors.
Within sectors/clusters, the HNO covers all relevant sub-sectors/areas of responsibility.
The HNO includes an inter-sectoral analysis.
The analysis for each sector considers gender and protection issues.
The HNO addresses other cross-cutting issues (e.g. age, disability, the environment, early recovery, and HIV/AIDS) where they are relevant.
The HNO covers all relevant affected groups (e.g. displaced and non-displaced affected people, casualties. See IMWG 2016 support package to the humanitarian profile).

Within affected groups, HNO results are broken down at least at level 3 of the humanitarian profile (i.e. distinguishing between dead, injured, missing, host and non-host communities, IDPs, refugees/asylum seekers, returnees and others of concern).
The HNO indicates which groups are particularly vulnerable in the given context (e.g. women, elderly, children, people with disabilities, minorities, etc.)
Results for relevant indicators are disaggregated by the vulnerable groups identified as per the previous criterion.

The HNO identifies relevant distinctions within vulnerable groups (e.g. different types of disabilities, different age groups within gender groups, different gender groups within minority groups, etc.).
The HNO is transparent about the number, types, dates and locations of the needs assessments used for the analysis.
The HNO assess the comprehensiveness and reliability of the information used for the analysis and is transparent about limitations and information gaps and their impact on key conclusions.
The HNO indicates sources or references for key findings, data and graphs.
The HNO is transparent about the methods used for calculating key humanitarian population figures and the severity of needs.
The HNO specifies probabilities, confidence levels and uncertainty attached to key findings, humanitarian population figures or conclusions.
Information used for calculating humanitarian population figures is based on representative surveys, involving randomly selected respondents.
Survey data used for calculating humanitarian population figures are at most three months old.
Different analytical lenses, such as gender, age, disability, and protection, are applied during the analysis.
The HNO team includes international and national members and is mixed in terms of institutional backgrounds, disciplines, and gender.
The HNO reports which humanitarian needs affected people and/or their representatives consider priority.
The HNO builds on information collected directly from the affected population rather than only via their representatives or sectoral experts in each key sector.
The HNO makes explicit whether there are differences between priorities expressed by men and women for each sector.
The HNO establishes which issues different vulnerable groups, including people with disabilities and other potentially marginalized and discriminated groups, see as priorities.
The HNO analysis is guided by a jointly agreed analytical framework, including a theoretical framework, a data collection and an analysis plan.
The HNO states whether there are any evidence-based alternative views, contrary information or dissenting explanations or interpretations.
The HNO makes assumptions explicit.
The HNO identifies key issues affecting people at sector and intersector level, including protection risks.

The HNO establishes the humanitarian profile of the crisis (types of affected groups and numbers). 
See IMWG 2016 Support package to the humanitarian profile
The HNO identifies what coping mechanisms affected people use to deal with the key crisis-related issues affecting them for each sector.
The HNO identifies the capacities of affected people and local authorities to cope with and respond to the crisis for each sector.
The HNO identifies the scope and reach of existing humanitarian assistance.
The HNO identifies the information needs and communication preferences of affected communities.

The HNO uses earlier data to establish trends or evolutions in the humanitarian situation at sector and intersector level and - where applicable - to compare current findings to the situation before the crisis.

The HNO identifies humanitarian access constraints, including obstacles for people in need in accessing assistance, constraints for humanitarian actors to access people in need and physical constraints.
The HNO identifies driver(s) and underlying factors of the main humanitarian issues at sector and intersector level.
The HNO estimates and compares the number of people in need per sector or thematic area and disaggregates results by severity class. --> See 2016 IMWG Humanitarian population figures
The HNO estimates and compares the number of people in need by geographical area and disaggregates results by severity class. --> See 2016 IMWG Humanitarian population figures
The HNO estimates and compares the number of people in need by affected group and disaggregates results by severity class.--> See 2016 IMWG Humanitarian population figures
The HNO estimates the overall number of people in need at inter-sector level and disaggregates results by severity class. --> See 2016 IMWG Humanitarian population figures
The HNO includes a projection of likely future humanitarian needs.
Preliminary or final results are shared with response planners in advance of the response analysis and the planning/decision-making process.
The HNO report includes an overview map and an executive summary of the main needs and key humanitarian population figures.
The report has a table of contents, is written in plain language and follows a logical structure.
Conclusions are presented clearly and concisely and supported by evidence and well-reasoned arguments.
Appropriate and effective visualizations (e.g. charts, maps, infographics) are used to illustrate the findings and support key conclusions.
The HNO report and the data are accessible on the most common humanitarian information platforms (e.g. HR.info, Reliefweb, HDX, UNHCR operational portal, cluster websites, etc.).
HNO results were presented to key actors and relevant decision-making fora at national and local level.
The HNO report has been translated into local languages so that local and national actors and affected people can use it.
The Humanitarian Response Plan / appeal references the HNO.
The Humanitarian Response Plan / appeal reflects the geographic priorities suggested by the HNO.
The Humanitarian Response Plan / appeal reflects the thematic and sectoral priorities suggested by the HNO.
The Humanitarian Response Plan / appeal reflects the priorities between different affected and vulnerable groups suggested by the HNO.
At the end of the HNO, partners review the assessment process, methodology and tools to identify lessons and improve assessment preparedness in-country and joint assessment practice in general.
A majority of interviewed cluster/sector representatives perceives the HNO as useful.
A majority of interviewed cluster/sector representatives perceives the HNO as unbiased.
Planning documents of a majority of consulted clusters/sectors reflect the geographic priorities suggested by the HNO.
Planning documents of a majority of consulted clusters/sectors reflect the thematic and sectoral priorities suggested by the HNO.
Planning documents of a majority of consulted clusters/sectors reflect the priorities between affected and vulnerable groups suggested by the HNO.
A majority of interviewed UN agencies perceives the HNO as useful.
A majority of interviewed UN agencies perceives the HNO as unbiased.
Planning documents of a majority of interviewed UN agencies reflect the geographic priorities suggested by the HNO.
Planning documents of a majority of interviewed UN agencies reflect the priorities between humanitarian sectors and sub-sectors suggested by the HNO.
Planning documents of a majority of interviewed UN agencies reflect the priorities between affected and vulnerable groups suggested by the HNO.
A majority of interviewed INGOs perceives the HNO as useful.
A majority of interviewed INGOs perceives the HNO as unbiased.
Planning documents of a majority of interviewed INGOs reflect the geographic priorities suggested by the HNO.
Planning documents of a majority of interviewed INGOs reflect the priorities between humanitarian sectors and sub-sectors suggested by the HNO.
Planning documents of a majority of interviewed INGOs reflect the priorities between affected and vulnerable groups suggested by the HNO.
A majority of interviewed local NGOs perceives the HNO as useful.
A majority of interviewed local NGOs perceives the HNO as unbiased.
Planning documents of a majority of interviewed local NGOs reflect the geographic priorities suggested by the HNO.
Planning documents of a majority of interviewed local NGOs reflect the priorities between humanitarian sectors and sub-sectors suggested by the HNO.
Planning documents of a majority of interviewed local NGOs reflect the priorities between affected and vulnerable groups suggested by the HNO.
A majority of interviewed Red Cross/Red Crescent representatives perceives the HNO as useful.
A majority of interviewed Red Cross/Red Crescent representatives perceives the HNO as unbiased.
Planning documents of a majority of consulted Red Cross/Red Crescent organizations reflect the geographic priorities suggested by the HNO.
Planning documents of a majority of consulted Red Cross/Red Crescent organizations reflect the priorities between humanitarian sectors and sub-sectors suggested by the HNO.
Planning documents of a majority of consulted Red Cross/Red Crescent organizations reflect the priorities between affected and vulnerable groups suggested by the HNO.
A majority of interviewed donor representatives perceives the HNO as useful.
A majority of interviewed donor representatives perceives the HNO as unbiased.
Planning documents of a majority of consulted donors reflect the geographic priorities suggested by the HNO.
Planning documents of a majority of consulted donors reflect the priorities between humanitarian sectors and sub-sectors suggested by the HNO.
Planning documents of a majority of consulted donors reflect the priorities between affected and vulnerable groups suggested by the HNO.
A majority of interviewed government representatives perceives the HNO as useful.
A majority of interviewed government representatives perceives the HNO as unbiased.
Government plans for the humanitarian response reflect the geographic priorities suggested by the HNO.
Government plans for the humanitarian response reflect the priorities between humanitarian sectors and sub-sectors suggested by the HNO.
Government plans for the humanitarian response reflect the priorities between affected and vulnerable groups suggested by the HNO.
A majority of interviewed development and stabilization actors is aware of the HNO.
A majority of interviewed development and stabilization actors perceives the HNO as useful.
A majority of interviewed development and stabilization actors perceives the HNO as unbiased.
A majority of interviewed development and stabilization actors states that they have considered HNO findings in their planning processes.

Within affected groups, HNO results are broken down at least at level 3 of the humanitarian profile (i.e. distinguishing between dead, injured, missing, host and non-host communities, IDPs, refugees/asylum seekers, returnees and others of concern).

The HNO analysis is guided by a jointly agreed analytical framework, including a theoretical framework, a data collection and an analysis plan.
The HNO states whether there are any evidence-based alternative views, contrary information or dissenting explanations or interpretations.
The HNO report and the data are accessible on the most common humanitarian information platforms (e.g. HR.info, Reliefweb, HDX, UNHCR operational portal, cluster websites, etc.).
HNO results were presented to key actors and relevant decision-making fora at national and local level.
The HNO report has been translated into local languages so that local and national actors and affected people can use it.
The HNO is transparent about the number, types, dates and locations of the needs assessments used for the analysis.
The HNO assess the comprehensiveness and reliability of the information used for the analysis and is transparent about limitations and information gaps and their impact on key conclusions.
The HNO indicates sources or references for key findings, data and graphs.
The HNO is transparent about the methods used for calculating key humanitarian population figures and the severity of needs.
The HNO specifies probabilities, confidence levels and uncertainty attached to key findings, humanitarian population figures or conclusions.
The HNO makes assumptions explicit.
Information used for calculating humanitarian population figures is based on representative surveys, involving randomly selected respondents.
Survey data used for calculating humanitarian population figures are at most three months old.
Different analytical lenses, such as gender, age, disability, and protection, are applied during the analysis.
The HNO team includes international and national members and is mixed in terms of institutional backgrounds, disciplines, and gender.
The HNO analysis is guided by a jointly agreed analytical framework, including a theoretical framework, a data collection and an analysis plan.
The HNO states whether there are any evidence-based alternative views, contrary information or dissenting explanations or interpretations.
The HNO makes assumptions explicit.
The report states the assessment's general and specific objectives in terms of geographic areas, sectors, thematic areas and population groups to be assessed.
Relevant decision makers, data experts, subject matter and context experts were involved in defining the objectives and the scope of the assessment to ensure it meets their information needs.
The assessment is explicit about which humanitarian planning exercise it aims to inform.

The assessment objectives and scope take into account existing information (e.g. assessment registry, secondary data review, lessons learnt from past assessments) and limit the burden of the assessment on the affected population by minimizing data collected.
The assessment's objectives include conducting an inter-sectoral analysis.
The sample of assessed areas includes all types of geographical areas relevant for the planning exercise the assessment aims to inform.

The sample design matches the geographic level of detail required by the planning process the assessment aims to inform, e.g. administrative levels 1 and 2 (province, district) for strategic planning, administrative levels 3 or 4 (sub district, commune or village) for operational planning.

The assessment covers all sectors (e.g. food security, shelter, education etc.) and sub-sectors (e.g. water supply, sanitation and hygiene for WASH) relevant for the planning exercise the assessment aims to inform.
Sector assessment experts were involved in identifying questions for each relevant sector or sub-sector.
Relevant cross-cutting issues (e.g. gender, age, disability, environment, and early recovery) are addressed in the questionnaire and the analysis.
The assessment includes open questions that allow for identifying 'new' or non-sector specific issues.
The assessment covers all groups potentially affected by the crisis (depending on context e.g. refugees, IDPs, host communities, affected residents, etc.).

Characteristics that increase the vulnerability of different groups in the given context (e.g. gender, age, disability, minority status, displacement, etc.) are identified when developing the questionnaire.
Results for relevant indicators are disaggregated by the characteristics identified as per the previous criterion.

The analysis identifies relevant distinctions within these groups (e.g. different types of disabilities, different age groups within gender groups, different gender groups within minority groups, etc.).
Data protection measures are in place to protect the identity of respondents, including safe storage, password protection and anonymization when sharing data.

Respondents are informed on how the data will be used and are formally asked if they are willing to participate through informed consent 
(-> See https://rescue.app.box.com/s/pknrxkzjoucjo9kh075fyy4qx476cg9z).
The assessment design is based on a "do no harm" analysis, identifies potential risks to affected populations and enumerators and provides relevant mitigation measures.

Strategies are in place to prevent and address sexual harassment, exploitation and abuse during the assessment process (this can include for example policies, guidance, briefings, training or complaints mechanisms).
Enumerators are trained in safety and security measures.
Enumerators are trained in sensitive data management, for example in how to engage with respondents who are minors.
Trainings for or instructions to enumerators and team leaders include procedures for the identification and referral of cases in need of immediate follow-up.
Trainings for or instructions to enumerators and team leaders include recommendations for managing expectations of affected communities.
Trainings for or instructions to enumerators and team leaders include modules on humanitarian principles.

Representatives from local and international NGOs, UN agencies, clusters, members of the Red Cross / Red Crescent Movement and where appropriate government / local authorities were invited to join the inter-agency assessment working group overseeing the assessment.
Unless withheld for security reasons, the assessment indicates which organizations were involved in design, data collection, analysis and report writing.
Assessment partners share relevant existing data, knowledge and resources to implement the assessment.
The assessment is transparent about the number, types and location of respondents interviewed.
The assessment indicates sources for secondary data, key findings and graphs.
The assessment is transparent about limitations and information gaps and their impact on key findings.
The assessment provides access to the instruments used for data collection.

Technical documentation that is publicly available or available on request (for example definitions of key concepts, methodological and processing notes, anonymized microdata) allows the reproduction of assessment results.
The assessment specifies probabilities, confidence levels and uncertainty attached to key findings, humanitarian population figures or conclusions.
The assessment triangulates information derived from different sources (such as secondary data, key informant interviews or household surveys).
The assessment triangulates information gathered through different methods.

The assessment uses an appropriate sampling strategy, which can involve random or non-random sampling 
(--> 2012 Operational guidance on coordinated needs assessments).
Different analytical lenses, such as gender, age, disability, and protection, are applied during the analysis.
The assessment team includes international and national members and is mixed in terms of institutional backgrounds, disciplines, and gender.
The assessment reports which humanitarian needs affected people and/or their representatives consider priority.
Affected people are directly consulted for the assessment (rather than through their representatives or experts).
The assessment reports which response modalities affected people would prefer (e.g. goods, services, cash or a mix of them).
The assessment makes explicit whether there are differences between priorities expressed by men and women.
The assessment establishes which issues different population groups, including people with disabilities and other potentially marginalized and discriminated groups, see as priorities.
Relevant findings and results are communicated back to affected people, using contextually appropriate means of communication.
Data collection tools are tested in the context before using them.
Enumerators are trained on assessment objectives, methodology, questionnaire and interview techniques.

The assessment design takes cultural and communication preferences of affected people into account, for example when choosing survey tools and dissemination methods, sampling strategy, sex and age of enumerators, etc.

Data collection instruments and related instructions for enumerators are translated into local language(s) where relevant. -> See IASC 2015 MIRA guidance and IMWG 2016 Humanitarian profile support guidance
Data collection and analysis are guided by a jointly agreed analytical framework, including a theoretical framework, a data collection and an analysis plan.
The assessment states whether there are any evidence-based alternative views, contrary information or dissenting explanations or interpretations.
The assessment makes assumptions explicit.
The assessment identifies the most important ways in which the crisis affects people, including protection risks.

The assessment establishes the humanitarian profile of the crisis (types of affected groups and numbers). 
-> See IASC 2011 Humanitarian profile guidance
The assessment identifies what coping mechanisms affected people use.
The assessment identifies capacities of affected people and local authorities to cope with and respond to the crisis.
The assessment identifies the scope and reach of existing humanitarian assistance.
The assessment identifies the information needs and communication preferences of affected communities.
The assessment uses earlier data to establish trends or evolutions in the humanitarian situation and - where applicable - to compare current findings to the situation before the crisis.

The assessment identifies humanitarian access constraints, including obstacles for people in need in accessing assistance, constraints for humanitarian actors to access people in need and physical constraints.
The assessment identifies factors that drive and explain humanitarian conditions.
The assessment estimates and compares the severity of humanitarian conditions and the number of people in need per sector or thematic area. --> See 2016 IMWG Humanitarian population figures
The assessment estimates and compares the severity of humanitarian conditions and the number of people in need by geographical area. --> See 2016 IMWG Humanitarian population figures
The assessment estimates and compares the severity of humanitarian conditions and the number of people in need by affected group.--> See 2016 IMWG Humanitarian population figures
The assessment is transparent on the method used to estimate the number of people in need and the severity of humanitarian conditions. --> See 2016 IMWG Humanitarian population figures
The assessment estimates the overall severity of humanitarian conditions and the overall number of people in need (at inter-sector level). --> See 2016 IMWG Humanitarian population figures
The assessment identifies certain and likely future events that might affect humanitarian conditions.
Preliminary or final results are shared with response planners in advance of the response analysis and the planning/decision-making process.
The report includes an executive summary that provides a good overview of the assessment's findings and conclusions.
The report has a table of contents, is written in plain language and follows a logical structure.
Conclusions are presented clearly and concisely and supported by evidence and well-reasoned arguments.
Appropriate and effective visualizations (e.g. charts, maps, infographics) are used to illustrate the findings and support key conclusions.
The assessment report is accessible on the most common humanitarian information platforms (e.g. HR.info, Reliefweb, HDX, UNHCR operational portal, cluster websites, etc.).
The assessment is accessible on relevant government and development information platforms.
Findings were presented to key actors and relevant decision-making fora at national and local level.
The assessment has been translated into local languages so that local and national actors and affected people can use it.
The Humanitarian Response Plan / appeal references the assessment.
The Humanitarian Response Plan / appeal reflects the geographic priorities suggested by the assessment.
The Humanitarian Response Plan / appeal reflects the thematic and sectoral priorities suggested by the assessment.
The Humanitarian Response Plan / appeal reflects the priorities between different affected and vulnerable groups suggested by the assessment.

At the end of the assessment, partners review the assessment process, methodology and tools to identify lessons and improve assessment preparedness in-country and joint assessment practice in general.

A majority of interviewed cluster/sector representatives perceives the assessment as unbiased.
Planning documents of a majority of consulted clusters/sectors reflect the geographic priorities suggested by the assessment.

The assessment's objectives include conducting an inter-sectoral analysis.

Strategies are in place to prevent and address sexual harassment, exploitation and abuse during the assessment process (this can include for example policies, guidance, briefings, training or complaints mechanisms).
Enumerators are trained in safety and security measures.
Enumerators are trained in sensitive data management, for example in how to engage with respondents who are minors.
Trainings for or instructions to enumerators and team leaders include procedures for the identification and referral of cases in need of immediate follow-up.
Enumerators are trained on assessment objectives, methodology, questionnaire and interview techniques.
Trainings for or instructions to enumerators and team leaders include modules on humanitarian principles.

The assessment objectives and scope take into account existing information (e.g. assessment registry, secondary data review, lessons learnt from past assessments) and limit the burden of the assessment on the affected population by minimizing data collected.

Representatives from local and international NGOs, UN agencies, clusters, members of the Red Cross / Red Crescent Movement and where appropriate government / local authorities were invited to join the inter-agency assessment working group overseeing the assessment.
Unless withheld for security reasons, the assessment indicates which organizations were involved in design, data collection, analysis and report writing.
Assessment partners share relevant existing data, knowledge and resources to implement the assessment.
The assessment triangulates information derived from different sources (such as secondary data, key informant interviews or household surveys).
The assessment triangulates information gathered through different methods.

The assessment uses an appropriate sampling strategy, which can involve random or non-random sampling 
(--> 2012 Operational guidance on coordinated needs assessments).
Different analytical lenses, such as gender, age, disability, and protection, are applied during the analysis.
The assessment team includes international and national members and is mixed in terms of institutional backgrounds, disciplines, and gender.
Data collection and analysis are guided by a jointly agreed analytical framework, including a theoretical framework, a data collection and an analysis plan.
The assessment states whether there are any evidence-based alternative views, contrary information or dissenting explanations or interpretations.
Data protection measures are in place to protect the identity of respondents, including safe storage, password protection and anonymization when sharing data.

Respondents are informed on how the data will be used and are formally asked if they are willing to participate through informed consent 
(-> See https://rescue.app.box.com/s/pknrxkzjoucjo9kh075fyy4qx476cg9z).
The assessment report is accessible on the most common humanitarian information platforms (e.g. HR.info, Reliefweb, HDX, UNHCR operational portal, cluster websites, etc.).
The assessment is accessible on relevant government and development information platforms.
Findings were presented to key actors and relevant decision-making fora at national and local level.
The assessment has been translated into local languages so that local and national actors and affected people can use it.
The assessment is transparent about the number, types and location of respondents interviewed.
The assessment indicates sources for secondary data, key findings and graphs.
The assessment is transparent about limitations and information gaps and their impact on key findings.
The assessment provides access to the instruments used for data collection.

Technical documentation that is publicly available or available on request (for example definitions of key concepts, methodological and processing notes, anonymized microdata) allows the reproduction of assessment results.
The assessment specifies probabilities, confidence levels and uncertainty attached to key findings, humanitarian population figures or conclusions.
The assessment makes assumptions explicit.
The assessment triangulates information derived from different sources (such as secondary data, key informant interviews or household surveys).
The assessment triangulates information gathered through different methods.

The assessment uses an appropriate sampling strategy, which can involve random or non-random sampling 
(--> 2012 Operational guidance on coordinated needs assessments).
Different analytical lenses, such as gender, age, disability, and protection, are applied during the analysis.
The assessment team includes international and national members and is mixed in terms of institutional backgrounds, disciplines, and gender.
Data collection and analysis are guided by a jointly agreed analytical framework, including a theoretical framework, a data collection and an analysis plan.
The assessment states whether there are any evidence-based alternative views, contrary information or dissenting explanations or interpretations.
The assessment makes assumptions explicit.
